specs/victoria/approved/evacuate-non-rec.message: Presently, Masakari can evacuate instances from a failed compute host either when ``evacuate_all_instances`` is enabled or when ``HA_enabled=True`` metadata is set to the instance. When a failed host goes back to system as a reserved host, it is required to make the compute host empty and be available at its full capacity. So it would be useful to clear off/evacuate non-recovery instances in shutoff status i.e. ``HA_enabled=False`` , and while doing so one should not clear instances like ``Canaria`` which is meant for monitoring the health of the compute host.
Indent it correctly by moving statement on left side by two spaces.

Presently, pacemaker cluster is not configured in gate to detect the failure of compute hosts, so it's not possible to send notification to masakari about compute host failure which would trigger to evacuate VMs running on the failed compute hosts on to another compute host. So it's not possible to test the changes specified in this spec until provision is made in CI gate job to configure and fence compute hosts using pacemaker cluster.

Cloud you give more information about scene why and how it evacuate non-recovery instances?

It's my understanding that the instances' status is update by nova-compute service. When nova-compute restart, it will set the instances to 'shutoff'. But when host failure, the instances already can't be used, and what's the meaning to set the non-recovery instances to shutoff?

This use case is for operators who wants to evacuate only those instances with metadata ``HA_enabled=True``. If there are any instances running with metadata ``HA_enabled=False``, then, all such instances will be evacuated but it's vm_state will be set to ``shutoff`` state.
It makes me confused. Whether to evacuate 'HA_enabled=False' instances?

I would suggest you to check "Matrix of various host failure config option (New/ Existing) combinations" section which explains what would happen in various config option combinations.

and then you can suggest what you would want to do for a particular combination.

We cann't know the tenant IDs to ignore when initialize the cloud platform. And the tenants may changes over time.
So the 'ignore_instances_for_projects' is not friendly to devopts.

The config option ``ignore_instances_for_projects`` is not meant to include ``project_ids`` of normal end users. As an operator when you want to run ``Canaria`` instances for monitoring of compute host, you will know the tenant_id in advance or after it's initialized you will need to restart the masakari services after updating the masakari conf file.

I got your point.
It can use 'ha_enable' metadata to identify such instances, and 'ignore_instances_for_projects' looks redundant.
To the product, if it can't be configurated automatically, it is not a good design. That's why I said it is not friendly to devops.

I can understand it's painful for DevOps but there are many other OpenStack services where they are managing to do the same thing like Nova scheduler filters: e.g. isolated host filter.

The other possible solution would be to add metadata to failover_segment in which you can specify the project_id that you would otherwise specify in ``ignore_instances_for_projects`` config option.

nova/scheduler/client/report.py.message:
I think this change is make sense.

If in 'rp' we have some children, that we can not delete the 'rp' in placement [1], it will be raised 'CannotDeleteParentResourceProvider', in this way, we cannot assign this 'rp' to the instance again.

We can delete 'rp' step by step until you delete the 'rp' resource, but we need to update this again when the Cybrog resource is synchronized, I see that you have dealt with this [2].

[1]https://opendev.org/openstack/placement/src/branch/master/placement/objects/resource_provider.py#L733-L734

[2]https://review.opendev.org/#/c/718662/1/cyborg/conductor/manager.py@181
to be precise placement will reject the delete request, the report client in nova raises the exception
do we know if this list in a good order for recursive deletion (e.g is it always contains the child before its ancestors)? The placement API does not define the order in which the RPs are returned.

> do we know if this list in a good order for recursive deletion (e.g
 > is it always contains the child before its ancestors)? The
 > placement API does not define the order in which the RPs are
 > returned.

The resource data store in ``resource_providers`` table in Placement, the table is stored in a tree structure, and the default storage structure returned by ``rp_uuid`` is, right?
Even if the placement storage strategy works this way it feels like an implementation detail in placement that can change without notice. Does nova make the same assumption elsewhere in the code?
I saw Cyborg also delete rp by this way https://opendev.org/openstack/cyborg/src/branch/master/cyborg/conductor/manager.py#L336-L345

Other pieces of nova also uses the result from get_providers_in_tree(). Like _ensure_resource_provider()[1] which then pass the list of provider dicts to populate_from_iterable()[2] which does not make any assumption of the orders of the RPs in the list. Instead it always search for the next RP that can be processed[3].

So I think we should not make the assumption about the order here either.


[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/10db1d8e55e0fdfa5bfe1a827b7e8aaf9b7feb7c/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L640
[2] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/10db1d8e55e0fdfa5bfe1a827b7e8aaf9b7feb7c/nova/scheduler/client/report.py#L658
[3] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/10db1d8e55e0fdfa5bfe1a827b7e8aaf9b7feb7c/nova/compute/provider_tree.py#L339

note to myself. If there are bandwidth RPs then those are created by neutron. Fortunately this recursive delete will not race with neutron as neutron only try to create / update things in placement if something changes in the neutron agent configuration.
so...I guess provider tree is empty when the service calling this method. But correct me if miss something
provider tree is not empty. But the "roots_by_uuid" of the provider tree is empty dict, so i init it at next patch, pls review.
OK, this is defined to return return the result of a pre-order traversal of the tree so the reversed order below L2160 makes sure that we try to delete children before parent.
Will do it in next patch.
As far as I see all the caller passes cascade = True so we can drop this parameter.

If we raise this up then we have to handle them at the caller side. I see two callers:

1) nova.api.openstack.compute.services.ServiceController.delete()
In this case some preconditions are checked before the delete (e.g. no instance or unfinished migration exists on the node) So if we still get a placement error then I think we should fail the service delete and return the error to the user.

2) nova.compute.manager.ComputeManager.update_available_resource()
This is a periodic case on the compute side so no user to notify about the error. Just catch these and log an error.

barbican_tempest_plugin/tests/scenario/b.message:
The cert_builder has to have the Basic Constraints and Key Usage extensions or else it can't be used as a trusted certificate (see https://github.com/openstack/cursive/blob/master/cursive/certificate_utils.py#L87 ).

This can be done with the following lines:

cert_builder = x509.CertificateBuilder(
            issuer_name=issuer, subject_name=issuer,
            public_key=private_key.public_key(),
            serial_number=x509.random_serial_number(),
            not_valid_before=datetime.utcnow(),
            not_valid_after=datetime.utcnow() + timedelta(days=10)
        ).add_extension(
            x509.BasicConstraints(
                ca=True,
                path_length=1
            ),
            critical=True
        ).add_extension(
            x509.KeyUsage(
                digital_signature=True,
                content_commitment=True,
                key_encipherment=False,
                data_encipherment=False,
                key_agreement=False,
                key_cert_sign=True,
                crl_sign=False,
                encipher_only=False,
                decipher_only=False
            ),
            critical=False
        )
Thank you, @Brianna. I had forgotten to include these extensions.

What makes this a bad signing certificate?  It looks like it will be valid, since it's based off of the same private key, and will have the same subject/issuer as the other certificate (thus looking like a parent certificate since both are self-signed).

One possibility is to generate a certificate without the proper KeyUsage and BasicConstraints extensions, or use a different subject than the other cert.

I'll get specific in the next revision.

How many services are we talking about here? Which services specifically?

* Gerrit
* Storyboard

Anything else? I feel this needs to be explicited so we can have an idea of the scope, and also be aware of the amount of support these services already have for third party Identity Providers.
I suppose if we want to embrace the idea of Zuul tenant admins this might be a good way to manage them, I'll mention it in the next rev, thanks!

I suppose that means if we want to rely on the same accounts for Gerrit users and Zuul tenant admins, we'd need them all in the same realm? I don't think we'd want users having to authenticate with a different realm depending on which project they're reviewing changes for anyway, and I guess it's entirely possible for one person to be an admin for multiple Zuul tenants, so maybe realms are only adding complexity there.

do we want to split the user bases in distinct realms ?

* OpenDev
* OpenStack
* ?

Zuul is already using tenants which could be mapped to realms, for example.
Be aware that gerrit does not support multiple realms, as far as I can tell. You'd need one gerrit instance per realm.

Do we also need to manage ACLs with the central auth ? Gerrit would be a special beast because it stores ACLs in a project's config branch; but OpenID Connect's token can include roles and groups claims that other services could use to figure out a user's ACLs.

I don't know, but if we gain that ability then it might be nice to have (for example StoryBoard currently lacks non-admin group management, to create or modify the membership of an SB team you have to be a global admin).

Yeah, and to be honest I think I'd still prefer to see things like group membership driven by structured data in a revision control system, so that we have the ability to make those changes reviewable and testable before they go into effect (this is my current plan for StoryBoard group management too, I have a straw man example at https://review.opendev.org/685778 awaiting time to implement).

So that's another thing to list for a future revision: do our services support role and group mappings from the JWT?

* Gerrit: no
* Storyboard: would be implemented along support for OIDC 
* Zuul: yes
...
Yep, I'll add a sentence mentioning it, thanks.
gerrit's OAuth2 plugin has extensive support for many identity providers: https://github.com/davido/gerrit-oauth-provider

Gerrit *wants* E-mail addresses to be unique, but its OpenID support has traditionally fallen short on this (it will happily autocreate more than one account with the same address if they're associated with different OpenIDs, and then break on things like group membership or requested reviewer addition because it assumes but does not enforce address uniqueness). Gerrit's actual "source of truth" for users *was* an autoincrement field in the accounts table, so an integer account ID number essentially, though with the recent switch to NoteDB I'm not positive that still holds true.

I'm in favor of the test you suggest if someone wants to give that a shot, but I'm fairly certain that at least up through Gerrit 2.15 you'll just autocreate an additional account with a conflicting E-mail address. Regardless, there are other ways around that problem if we deem it critical to solve.

I think gerrit's source of truth for users is emails. ie if you activate gerrit's oauth plugin on an instance where users have already been registered, the mapping should be done through registered emails.

It wouldn't be too difficult to confirm:
1. spawn a test gerrit using UbuntuOne authentication
2. Have users do some stuff on the test instance, so that they're registered there
3. Switch to oauth
4. Have users log in again (make sure they're known by the same email than with U1 on the new oauth Identity Provider)
5. Make sure they're mapped to the right user

We'd need to make sure other services currently using U1 would behave similarly; if it's the case it would greatly simplify migration, as we'd have to simply ask returning users to choose an identity provider where they're registered with the same e-mail as U1.

Yes, we discussed it at the PTG as well, a number of the options (including Keycloak) would probably allow us to prevent accounts with duplicate addresses for the most part. I can still think of slightly pathological scenarios where that's not preventable though (for example I authenticate to Keycloak and confirm my E-mail address, then log into Gerrit with that ID, later I change my E-mail address for that Keycloak ID but also log into Keycloak again autocreating a new ID not associated with the original and set the earlier address, then log into Gerrit again with that, resulting in autocreated accounts in Gerrit with different Keycloak IDs but colliding E-mail addresses). It's also possible newer versions of Gerrit have gotten better about refusing to autocreate an account when the same address is already associated with an existing account.

I'd say Keycloak offers a solution for this, as it allows users to link accounts: https://www.keycloak.org/docs/latest/server_admin/index.html#automatically-link-existing-first-login-flow

Thus keycloak would handle the problem of multiple OpenIDs for the same email.
Is there anybody we can contact about this? See if we can help UbuntuOne with supporting newer standards?

We've tried in the past, and if someone would like to reach out to Canonical again that's cool with me, though they've seemed content to only ever touch the codebase when changes are needed for supporting their own products, and there has been repeated exodus of developers from the project leaving it at times with basically no caretakers whatsoever... I do not know its current state of maintenance however.
+1 for adding Keycloak

This is definitely not true. Ipsilon works perfectly fine with regular LDAP systems and is commonly used to provide OpenID service. It also has GSSAPI and PAM info/auth plugins in the source tree. And the latest sources[0] contain theming support, with Fedora Account System and openSUSE Login themes currently present in-tree.

Fedora[1], RPM Fusion[2], and GNOME[3] do use Ipsilon with FreeIPA, but openSUSE[4] uses it with OpenLDAP.

[0]: https://pagure.io/ipsilon
[1]: https://id.fedoraproject.org
[2]: https://id.rpmfusion.org
[3]: https://id.gnome.org
[4]: https://id.opensuse.org

We had an Ipsilon PoC circa 2015 as our first attempt at solving this problem, and so much of the prose here was taken from E-mail discussions several years old now. Thanks for the corrections!

Would it be accurate to say though that Ipsilon expects some sort of user database (whether that's provided by FreeIPA, OpenLDAP, et cetera) and can't act merely as an ID passthrough/aggregation for other external IDPs?
I think it already supports generic OAuth2 setups. but if not, adding support would be rather straightforward based on existing ones.
Thanks, I'll note this.
FYI: implemented by this change https://review.opendev.org/#/c/735586/

Three shall be the number of the counting and the number of the counting shall be three. ;)

But sure, I'll correct this on the next revision.
five :)

One key bit that came out of the virtual PTG is that we can likely use something like https://simplesamlphp.org/ to act as a go between an identity broker that supports saml auth and launchpad/ubuntuone with its openid v1 auth.

I think this is worth calling out somewhere in the spec since this particular issue has historically been the major hangup for making any progress on this idea.

Gerrit's oauth plugin supports keycloak starting in the 2.14 version. We run 2.13 but plan to upgrade and chances are we could backport keycloak support to 2.13 is absolutely necessary.

https://gerrit.googlesource.com/plugins/oauth/+/refs/heads/stable-2.14/README.md

I don't think anyone was happy with dropping ubuntu one support at least at the beginning of this process. Doing so would almost certainly require user unfriendly processes to get things mapped up in the new account system properly.
Is this still necessary? On line 338 above you mention OIDC support is tested and working with storyboard. Tools like keycloak tend to support oauth v2, oidc, and saml.

In our PTG conversations there seemed to be very good reasons to use Keycloak + SimpleSMLphp as a compat layer for ubuntu one.

Maybe we should update the spec to include this as the suggested path forward so that we can properly evaluate it?
Agreed, I'll update this paragraph to make these points clearer. Thanks!

I feel like the conclusion here (unsure what software) dosen't quite match the conclusion below (kinda looks like keycloak).  But I get that they do both agree that we're not sure yet, and below we're saying let's test keycloak and see if it works.  Not sure if any text actually warrants changing.  :)

I think some kind of support for launchpad/openidv1 is relatively important and would prefer we do that (either direct implementation or saml shim) rather than ETL or similar.  If we end up with anything other than upstreamed openidv1 support, then I think treating that as a 6-month temporary situation is reasonable; if we do get upstream support, then I think we could continue to support launchpad indefinitely.  Not sure if this warrants an explicit mention.  Could probably wait until after the POC.

web/src/containers/config/Config.jsx.message: Since we now have PF4 in place, wouldn't it make sense to directly use equivalent PF4 components for coming changes?

Do we need all this styling? I think the item should look similar to the others without applying any additional styling. Also, I don't think this item should be smaller (font-size: 11px) than others in the header toolbar. All in all, I think the item looks fine without these additional styles.

Just noticed that the timezone selection has similar styles. But I think they are not needed anymore for the new layout using PF4 and could also be removed there.

You can check out the code for the navigation bar in the App.jsx file or the first example here https://www.patternfly.org/v4/documentation/react/demos/pagelayout#default-nav (just click on the "JSX" link below the preview image to show the source code). I also took this example to style the navigation bar in the initial PF4 change.

I would prefer using a cog icon https://fontawesome.com/icons/cog?style=solid instead. IMHO that's the commonly used icon for a settings dialog.

Also the PF4 design guide recommends using the cog icon over the old settings icon https://www.patternfly.org/v4/design-guidelines/styles/icons (just search for "settings" on this site).

Although this element provides an onClick handler, I think it should also be wrapped into something clickable (so it also provides the necessary pointer style - like a button).

This would be similar to the other items in the PageHeaderTools section (just without additional text and an onClick handler instead of a Link):

<Button variant={ButtonVariant.plain} onClick={this.handleModalToggle}>
  <CogIcon />
</Button>

nit 1: A React.Fragment should only be used in case you don't want to wrap the components/tags into another component/tag (e.g. a div). That's sometimes necessary to provide a single output element for render() functions. I think in this it's ok to wrap everything in a div.

nit 2: For me the focus marker of the switch is cut at the bottom. Maybe you could fix this by adding a slight padding-bottom (10px) to the wrapper div. I would assume that PF4 deals with that by itself but that doesn't seem to be the case (at least on my machine :D )
I'm not sure if that's related to the way the value is looked up from the localstorage, but in my case, the switch always show the wrong value (disabled when true, enabled when false).

This stands out to me because we've got a separate save action which saves the state as is. Looking at render() is the !autoReload here correct? the isChecked value seems to be set to autoReload so we'll invert this value? Shouldn't we take the non inverted value to reflect the check state instead?
handlerAutoReload is called when you click the toggle button, which always switches old status. AFAIK that is how a toggle is supposed to work.
I like the explicit prevState version. Seems reasonable to do in a follow on.

Are there other possibilities to close the modal or only this button? In case there are others, I would prefer to really close it here (e.g. implement something like this.handleModalClose) and not rely on the toggle as this then might come out of sync depending on which actions where taken in the UI.
Yes, ESC also works but is documented to call onClose. I am not aware of other methods.

web/src/pages/Status.jsx.message:
Is there any specific reason why we enforce the upload here? This looks like we are now not taking the autoReload setting in account.

The same applies for the componentDidMount() function, although this is only called once in the beginning, so it might be OK to enforce an initial loading there. Still, previously this wasn't necessary, so I'm wondering why it's necessary now?

This runs when the user just switched tenants.  The intent of disabling auto-update is to avoid wasting bandwidth.  If the user actively changes what they're looking at, we should show them new, correct data, not old data from the wrong tenant.

Well to an extent, this is already possible today isn't it? Should we be a bit more clear about the side effects that the user would see if the FIP is associated to a fixed IP of a port that's sitting on a segment of a routed network?

Question: For migration purposes to routed_networks (until this spec is implemented), is it possible that (data model wise) a network that has a segment_indentifier (so a segment of a routed network) can be associated to a neutron router.

I understand that neutron may not be able to make a functioning implementation without this spec implemented.  But I was talking with Miguel about how we can migrate our current setup over to using routed networks.  Right now have a bunch of provider networks, that we associate to two routers.  One router handles public ip's another handles floating ips.  We then extended the L3 classes to let neutron do its normal stuff for association, then we call into our own api's to actually route the ip in the network.  the reverse is done for dis-associating an ip.  We do not run an L3-agent anywhere except when we are adding new networks via the api.  So we dont care if the router itself actually works (since we do the work of making the ip work).  We only care that neutron api will let us associate/disassociate ips (ie the data model works)

The plan would be to move each of those provider networks into a routed network by creating a new routed network and moving in each existing networks in as segments.  Then once this spec is implemented to attempt to migrate the existing floating ip's over to using this new functionality and remove our custom code.

The way I understand this is that router:external networks don't quite fully work when they are segmented and thus still only operate on the assumption that they are a single broadcast domain. Am I barking up at the wrong tree?
a (possibly) unrelated question. How do address scopes work with routed networks? Do we know what happens when we use them together?

I had a similar question on this topic. 
While using routed networks, is it allowed to use Address scopes in combination.
Because if address scopes are used then, the floatingIP are void for the same scope (internal and external network).

Still not clear on how this internal floatingIP to external floatingIP translation will take place.
Adding a picture or more description would be helpfull to understand this.

We would also like if we could either:
1.) update allowed-address pairs to permit the associated floating ip

2.) extend the anti-spoofing rules to allow traffic for the ip to pass.  

My preference would be that I would like to see the anti-spoofing rules extended - so that I had the option of keeping allowed-address-pairs locked down to specific users.

While using DVR routers, is it ok to still route traffic between two segments internally or should we prevent any routing happening through the internal routers and make sure the routing only happens outside the neutron controlled routers.
don't know how many times I said this is an old template, meh :)

specs/train/routed-networks-floating-ips.message: This needs a neutron Router connected to both private network (router interface) and public network (router gateway), so how to accomplish this association here? For routed network, the neutron Router is necessary or not?

A neutron router is necessary. The workflow is to connect the router gateway interface to the external network, just as you do now. In my environment, the rack (ie segment) that has my network nodes (which are optional here with the exception of DHCP by the way) has a subnet with a service type of "network:router_gateway". The centralized router magically ends up scheduled on that segment, proper use of subnet service types makes this work flawlessly.

I'll spin a new patch set that shows an example of this all in action. My PoC environment demonstrates that the only change required to make any of this work is to relax the segment-subnet constraints on routed networks. It constitutes a rather solid reference architecture, and with one single patch we could unlock powerful functionality. Strategic use of existing features including subnet service types, address scopes, subnet pools, and BGP makes this all work.
Yes, we route it, not NAT, right? The floating IP will still be set to one device in the namespace? If not, then, which device/who will answer the floating IP ARP?

You have to route the floating IP. On the segment, ARP for the floating IP would be answered by the FIP gateway port. However, from outside the segment you have to involve routing to figure out where the FIP actually is. Nothing changes from a DVR perspective, we would have DVR assign the FIP to the FIP gateway port as it already does.

DVR already knows how to apply FIP's to the FIP gateway (it's segment-agnostic), the only piece missing is to allow a subnet that is not bound to a segment to be created on the external network. There is no change to DVR involved here.

With regard to ARP: as I mentioned earlier the upstream router would theoretically be able to ARP for the FIP, however in practice you would never see it do that because BGP would be telling it to route the /32.

See https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/6ba8d8d6f4993467dc48acb9a665933ea194ca2e/neutron/db/ipam_backend_mixin.py#L318 . I'm not yet sure of what the implications of simply relaxing this constraint altogether are, but it does seem like the easiest and least invasive way of implementing this spec.
Or add a basic workflow from the user's perspective?

There is no impact to the workflow of a tenant. They still simply create a router, then set up the gateway interface, and attach floating IP's just as they do today.

The operator impact is simply around learning how to use things that already exist in neutron like routed provider networks, address scopes, subnet pools, subnet service types, and neutron-dynamic-routing. By fixing this one thing (allowing a subnet to not be bound to a segment), this becomes simply a documentation exercise.

Oops, forgot to remove this bit. I'm proposing we not go through with this API change anymore. Keep it simple and relax the constraints on subnet creation on routed networks. BGP can take it from there (I think...)
Just a note: there are no tempest tests for the routed provider networks feature.

Just a note: actually as I see there are no API tests (nor functional or fullstack as I see) for routed provider networks feature.
I started to add to tempest, see:
https://review.opendev.org/665155

As I see it would be good to have some tests for the whole feature before moving forward with new functionality.

Btw: For fullstack tests the minimal placement server can be used which was added to test the bandwidth feature (see: https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/src/branch/master/neutron/tests/fullstack/servers/placement.py).
Why "network:floatingip" is not enough for a subnet to be allocated in a routed network?

We need network:routed for the exact reason that is described here: to allow the subnet to *not* be bound to a specific segment. Having *only* network:floatingip is a valid configuration, but it would be different from a subnet which also has network:routed.

A subnet with network:floatingip with a segmented network will have different floatingip ranges depending on the segment.

A subnet with both network:floatingip and network:routed will be in used on all segments, and will use the provider network as the next BGP HOP.
same here, why do we need another type?

There's no need for a *new* type, as this type already exist. This type is used in the provider network, so that floating IPs can use these IPs as next BGP HOP, and we need to make sure the range is used *only* for this (and nothing else).

container_config_scripts/pacemaker_resou.message:
In this transactional CIB shadowing approach there is a corner case I can foresee. What if "live" CIB contains an obsolete lock that can never be pushed for cleaning it up because of reasons?

What I propose is to store requester/expiry info in tmpfiles instead, given some fixed prefix (lockholderXXX), and only have a *link* to that file for that property.

Then, as an initialization entry action of this script, an "offline" (no access required to live/shadow CIBs) lookup can be performed against /tmp/lockholder* to verify consistency of locks and guarantee its expiration. If there is at least one lockholder info file found during that init action:
* sort them by the timestamp, if more > 1
* get the oldest one, check by its TTL if it has to be expired
* patch the *live* CIB on-fly to remove that TTL violation.
* repeat this for other lockholder info files discovered, if any

So then we can guarantee that CIB will never be "locked" without an opportunity to expire its obsolete lock properties.

You're probably right. I was thinking about a per-node local view into its locks in order to make expiration & cleanup decisions without accessing CIB. Then remove the matching CIB properties on-fly, so that expired locks removal cannot be failed because the snapshot epoch does not match the live one anymore.
...also, that init action must 1-by-1 remove any lock properties from the live CIB, if any found there without the corresponding lockholder info file existing (like after a node has rebooted)
I am not sure I follow this. In tmpfiles the info would not be clusterwide. Also the locks have an expiry so even if a reboot takes place, we'll just leverage the expiry date to ignore a stale lock.
is it safe to store cib in world read tmpfiles? Unsure if it can hold any sensitive data.

Ops... I think we can! My bad :D

If populate_agents is already using 'agent_chassis_table', then won't chassis already be stored/passed as the proper chassis/chassis_private row based on whether Chassis_Private exists? And then would we need to pass both chassis/chassis_private to the NeutronAgent() below? Or is the agent API code confusing me again? :p

Heh it is confusing indeed. There are two reason why we need to pass both row instances there:

1) The Chassis_Private table only contains a subset of information from the Chassis table. For example, the hostname or other_config columns are not present in the Private_Chassis table.

2) Now, the Chassis nb_cfg column is always 0 (zero). When we bump the nb_cfg value in the Global table the ovn-controller will bump the nb_cfg value in the Chassis_Private table only.

So, in order to satisfy the agents API we need information from both of these tables.
Nice one, let me give it a go!

Oh that would be great! Having access to the parsed json schema pre-connection will be very useful I think.

Something to think about whenever we do the get_connection/get_ovn_idls refactor. :p

Side note: I have grown to *hate* this function and get_ovn_idls. I can never actually follow what class is being instantiated where. I can say this, because I wrote the first version of it. :p
lol at some point I understood these methods but it always confuses me as well, I need to look at it a couple of times before I start making sense of it. We need to refactor this part of the code.

I think we can make this a lot simpler by just inspecting the returned SchemaHelper object. It has a public schema_json attribute: https://github.com/openvswitch/ovs/blob/5601e86c4ec5268cf11b1b92308fd85a7b5cc0ab/python/ovs/db/idl.py#L1960

which includes the tables in the schema. So we should just be able to do:

 if 'Chassis_Private' in helper.schema_json['tables']:
     helper.register_table('Chassis_Private')

and not deal with passing in chassis_private to the class, which I think will simplify things quite a bit (e.g., most impl_idl.py changes go away)
